questions.text: A patient exposed to radiation presents with severe nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea within a few days. Based on these symptoms, what is the expected radiation dose that has likely caused this Gastrointestinal Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Gastrointestinal syndrome occurs at radiation doses greater than 5 Gy, with significant symptoms emerging primarily in the 5-20 Gy range. It is characterised by severe nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea, indicating serious gastrointestinal distress from radiation exposure.

 

Acute Radiation Syndrome (ARS):

  • It refers to symptoms following whole-body or significant partial-body exposure to high doses of radiation (>1 Gy).
  • LD50/60, or Lethal Dose 50/60, is the radiation dose expected to cause death in 50% of the exposed population within 60 days.
  • An LD50/60 of approximately 4.5 Gy indicates that this level of whole-body radiation can lead to 50% mortality without medical intervention.
  • Clinical Phases of ARS:

Phase

Time Post-Exposure

Symptoms/Outcomes

Prodromal Phase

0–2 days

Nausea, vomiting, anorexia, fever, headache, early skin erythema (suggesting significant exposure >2 Gy)

Latent Phase

2–20 days

Temporary symptom improvement; abnormal lab results (lymphopenia, granulocytopenia) despite feeling well

Manifest Illness Phase

21–60 days

Symptoms vary by syndrome:

  • Hematopoietic syndrome (1-8 Gy, death in months):
  • Gastrointestinal syndrome (>5 Gy, death in 2 weeks)
  • Neurovascular syndrome (>20 Gy, death within 48 hours)

Final Phase

Recovery or Death

The outcome depends on the absorbed dose, dose rate, and exposure heterogeneity.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female has recently started working in the radiology department and is concerned about radiation exposure. She seeks advice from the occupational health department. According to AERB guidelines, what is the maximum dose limit for occupational workers exposed to whole-body radiation in a year?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 30 mSv

According to the Atomic Energy Regulatory Board (AERB) guidelines, the maximum dose limit for occupational workers exposed to whole-body radiation in any given year is 30 mSv. However, the average annual dose limit over five years should not exceed 20 mSv per year.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male who recently joined the radiology department was instructed to wear the device shown in the image. Which of the following statements about this device is incorrect?

choices.text: Assess the amount of radiation exposure
Should be sent for dose monitoring every 3 months
It is worn over the lead apron

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) It is worn over the lead apron

The image depicts a TLD (Thermoluminescent Dosimeter) Badge which is worn beneath the lead apron to accurately measure the radiation dose (Option A) that penetrates the body.

TLD (Thermoluminescent Dosimeter) Badge

Purpose

It is worn by individuals in radiation-exposed environments, such as medical imaging or nuclear facilities, to track their radiation dose and ensure it stays within safe limits.

Location

Worn beneath the lead apron (as lead apron cuts off some radiation)

Duration

According to the Atomic Energy Regulatory Board (AERB) of India, TLD badges are generally replaced and analyzed every 3 months to assess cumulative radiation exposure. (Option C)

Composition

Thermoluminescent phosphor crystals: (Option B)

  • Calcium sulfate dysprosium
  • Lithium fluoride
  • Lithium borate
  • Berrylium oxide

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient with a history of breast cancer is scheduled for a follow-up PET scan. During the consultation, she expresses concern about the long-term effects of radiation exposure. Which of the following statements regarding the stochastic effects of radiation exposure is correct?

choices.text: The severity of the effects is dose-dependent
It can also result in radiation-induced cataracts
No threshold dose is required for the occurrence

questions.solution:
The condition described is a case of radiation-induced cancer resulting from stochastic effects, a type of radiation effect that does not require a threshold dose for occurrence.

 

Types of Radiation Effects:

 

Deterministic Effects

Stochastic Effects

Threshold dose

Required

Not required (occur by chance, at any dose) (Option C)

Severity

Dose-dependent (Option A)

Dose-independent
Dose increased

Severity increases

The probability of occurrence increases

Examples 
  • Radiation-induced cataract (Option B)
  • Skin erythema (most common side effect)
  • Radiation-induced cancer (most common is Leukemia)
  • Congenital malformations
  • Mutations

questions.text: In the context of the ALARA (As Low As Reasonably Achievable) principle, which of the following strategies is not aligned with minimising radiation exposure for healthcare workers during interventional procedures?

choices.text: Increasing the distance between the operator and the radiation source.
Continuous fluoroscopy instead of Pulsed fluoroscopy
Implementing lead shielding and personal protective equipment (PPE).
Reducing the duration of time the patient is exposed to radiation.

questions.solution:
Continuous fluoroscopy results in higher radiation exposure compared to pulsed fluoroscopy, which does not align with the ALARA Principle.

 

ALARA (As Low As Reasonably Achievable)

  • Principle: It serves as a guiding framework for minimising radiation exposure during diagnostic and interventional procedures. Its core application is to reduce radiation exposure while maintaining the quality of medical procedures.
  • Strategies for reducing radiation exposure:
    • Increase distance (Option A ruled out): According to the inverse square law, radiation exposure decreases significantly with increased distance from the source.
    • Use shielding (Option C ruled out): Employ physical barriers to block radiation, such as personal protective equipment (PPE) like lead aprons and thyroid collars, along with architectural shielding in facilities (e.g., concrete walls in X-ray rooms).

 

Reduce time (Option D): Minimizing the duration of exposure during procedures is crucial, as shorter exposure times directly reduce the risk for both patients and healthcare workers.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman arrives at the emergency department with acute abdominal pain. The attending physician is considering an abdominal X-ray. What does the "10-day rule" advise regarding X-ray exposure for women of childbearing age?

choices.text: A gap of at least 10 days between two successive X-rays.
Avoid non-urgent X-rays within 10 days post-menstruation
Perform X-rays during the first 10 days of the menstrual cycle.
X-rays should be avoided 10 days before menstruation.

questions.solution:
• The "10-day rule for Radiological Examination of women of childbearing age:" is a radiology guideline used to minimize the risk of radiation exposure to a potentially pregnant woman.
  • Proposed by the International Commission on Radiological Protection (ICRP).
  • It states that radiological examinations of the lower abdomen and pelvis should be conducted, whenever possible, within the first 10 days following the onset of menstruation unless pregnancy is excluded.
  • In early pregnancy, radiation exposure, especially during organogenesis (weeks 3-8 post-conception), can lead to teratogenic effects (e.g., congenital anomalies), increased risk of miscarriage, or even fetal growth restriction.
  • This rule helps to prevent radiation exposure during early pregnancy that can potentially harm the developing embryo.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient is scheduled for a CT scan to evaluate abdominal pain. The radiologist aims to ensure adequate visualization of the bowel without creating significant contrast between the bowel contents and surrounding tissues. Which of the following is a neutral contrast agent appropriate for this procedure?
questions.solution:
Water is used as a neutral contrast agent to avoid altering the visibility of surrounding tissues while ensuring adequate visualization of the bowel.

Contrast media are substances used in medical imaging to enhance the visibility of structures within the body.

 

Type of Contrast Media

Description

Examples

Positive contrast media

Appear white on X-ray images due to greater attenuation of X-rays than surrounding tissues.
  • Barium (Option A),
  • Iodinated solutions (Option B)

Negative contrast media

Appear black due to less attenuation of X-rays than surrounding tissues.
  • Air (Option C)
  • Carbon dioxide

Neutral contrast media

Do not significantly alter X-ray attenuation, providing balanced contrast without adding brightness or darkness to the images.
  • Water
  • Mannitol (draws water into bowel loop)

questions.text: A 42-year-old female with a history of ulcerative colitis presents with severe abdominal pain and diarrhoea. The gastroenterologist is considering performing a barium study to assess her condition. Which of the following conditions would contraindicate using a barium study in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) exacerbation

  • Barium contrast study is contraindicated in Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) exacerbation (acute inflammation) as it poses a risk of perforation, where barium can leak into the abdominal cavity, leading to peritonitis and severe complications.
  • Barium contrast is a water-insoluble substance used in imaging studies to enhance the visualization of the GI tract, aiding in the assessment of conditions like gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), esophageal strictures, tumors, diverticulosis, ulcers and motility disorders.

  • Contraindications of Barium Study:

  1. GI Perforation: Can lead to peritonitis or mediastinitis.
  2. Bowel Obstruction: May exacerbate the obstruction and increase the risk of perforation.
  3. Tracheoesophageal Fistula: Risk of aspiration leading to pneumonia; iso-osmolar or low-osmolar non-ionic contrast is preferred.
  4. Acute Abdominal Inflammation: Risk of perforation and severe complications.

 

Types of Barium Studies

Type

Conditions

Barium Swallow
  • To evaluate normal swallowing function.
  • Suspected oesophagal disorders (e.g., strictures, tumours)
  • Achalasia cardia
  • Zenkers diverticulum
  • Hiatus hernia

Barium Meal
  • To evaluate normal gastric emptying
  • Evaluation of gastric and duodenal conditions (e.g., ulcers, carcinoma, pyloric stenosis)

Barium Meal Follow-Through
  • Assessment of small bowel disorders
  • Malabsorption syndrome (Option A)
  • Ileocecal TB (Option C)

Barium Enema
  • Assessment of lower gastrointestinal tract (e.g. Colonic carcinoma) (Option B)

questions.text: A 35-year-old pregnant woman is being assessed for suspected appendicitis. An abdominal ultrasound shows inflammation but in limited detail. What is the best contrast agent to enhance USG?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Sulfur Hexafluoride microbubbles

  • In contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS), microbubbles or microspheres, such as those found in Sonovist and Levovist, contain sulfur hexafluoride gas encapsulated in a phospholipid shell.
  • These microbubbles improve the visualization of blood flow and enhance the imaging of vascular structures and lesions.
  • Another type of microbubble in CEUS consists of octafluoropropane gas within a phospholipid shell.

 

Contrast agents for USG

Examples
  • Sonovue (sulfur hexafluoride)
  • Lumason (sulfur hexafluoride)
  • Definity (perflutren)
  • Sonozoid (perflubutane)

Preferred route

Intravenous

Eliminated by

Lungs (hence safe in Renal conditions)

Indications
  • Liver lesions
  • Micturating cystosonography
  • Renal lesions
  • Obstruction in Crohn's disease
  • Evaluation of Aortic aneurysm repair

Adverse Effects

It is the safest contrast media and rarely causes mild anaphylactoid reactions.


 

Barium sulfate (Option A) is the most commonly used contrast agent for identifying gastrointestinal tract issues such as ulcers, tumours, strictures, or inflammation. It is not water-soluble and is given orally or rectally.

 

Iodinated contrast agents (Option B) are water-soluble and are widely used for X-rays, CT scans, and interventional radiology. However, they are highly nephrotoxic and should be used with caution in patients with renal impairment only after evaluating renal function.


Saline solution (Option C) enhances the visualisation of internal structures, such as in saline infusion sonohysterography and hysterosalpingo-contrast sonography, which is mixed with air to improve the visibility of fallopian tubes and identify peritoneal spills.

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with multiple comorbidities is being evaluated for contrast-enhanced imaging. The healthcare team is assessing risk factors for contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN). Which of the following is NOT considered a risk factor for CIN?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) History of asthma

Previous history of asthma is not considered a risk factor for nephrotoxicity related to contrast media.

 

Contrast-induced Nephropathy: (Contrast-Induced Acute Kidney Injury (AKI))

  • Defined as an increase in serum creatinine by > 0.5 mg/dL or a > 25% rise from the baseline within 3 days of contrast administration, without any other clear cause.
  • Patients at higher risk for CIN typically include those with:
    • A history of renal disease
    • Diabetes (Option A ruled out)
    • Use of metformin (Option B ruled out)
    • Use of aminoglycosides
    • Chronic use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) (Option C ruled out)

Prevention: Hydration with intravenous saline (0.9%) is recommended at a rate of 100 mL/h, starting 12 hours before the angiography and continuing for 12 hours after the procedure.
